https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S1381116912004153/gr3/THUMBNAIL/image/gif/8c40cf6406b6e9b706dd4256e4b96ff1/gr3.sml gr3 gr3.sml sml 5111 164 207 IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8616 S1381-1169(12)00415-3 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.12.009 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 HCl at saturation concentration was obtained in various solvents. 1. Sulfuric acid in dropping funnel. 2. Sodium chloride in four-neck flask. 3. HCl in different solvent. 4. Electro thermal water bath.5 Electronic balance. 6. Residual gas absorption apparatus. Fig. 2 SEM micrographs of prepared acyl-PSt microspheres before (1(a) and 1(b)) and after (2(a) and 2(b)) washing steps. Fig. 3 FT/IR spectra of PSt microspheres before (black) and after (red) acylation. Fig. 4 (a) Effect of HCl on the Zeta (ζ) potential of acylation solvents. Fig. 5 Effect of HCl on the conductivity of acylation solvents. Fig. 6 (a) HCl inhibition on the PSt Friedel–Crafts acylation processes in different solvents: □ methanol, ○ acetone, ♢ chloroform; (b) In situ HCl removal enhanced PSt Friedel–Crafts acylation processes in different solvents. Fig. 7 LSCM of FC acylation on microsphere, a, HCl inhibition process in chloroform b, in situ HCl removal enhanced acylation processes in chloroform. Fig. 8 PSt Friedel–Crafts acylation processes affected by factors including (a) PSt diameter, (b) solvent volume, (c) Lewis-acids and reaction time, (d) catalyst amount, (e) acylation reagent, (f) reaction temperature and (g) fed-batch reaction. Scheme 1 Table 1 Solubility of HCl in different FC acylation solvents. Solvent Solubility (g/100g solvent) Relative polarity a 0°C 25°C Water b Miscible Miscible 1.0 Methanol 100.2 61.6 0.762 Ethanol 71.3 50.5 0.654 Acetone c 57.9 42.5 0.355 n-Butanol 50.2 38.5 0.586 Glycerol 33.5 26.1 0.812 n-Hexane 1.2 0.8 0.009 Chloroform 0.9 0.4 0.259 a The values for relative polarity were normalized from measurements of solvent shifts of absorption spectra [25]. b Water cannot be used as the FC acylation solvent in this study. c Acetone turning red. In situ inhibitor (HCl) removal promoted heterogeneous Friedel–Crafts reaction of polystyrene microsphere with Lewis acids catalysts Qiang Li Rongyue Zhang Juan Li Xiaofeng Yan Lianyan Wang Fangling Gong ⁎ Zhiguo Su Guanghui Ma ⁎ National Key Lab of Biochemical Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 010 82627072; fax: +86 010 82627072. Graphical abstract With the need for more catalyst activity and economically benign processes, in situ mineral acid removal can avoid direct contact between by-product and Lewis-acids in liquid environment, and increase the yield of a given catalysis process by overcoming inhibitory or toxic effects of by-product to allow continuous formation at maximal production level. Highlights ► Acid proton inhibited the heterogeneous Friedel–Crafts reaction. ► Remove the by-product from the vicinity of the catalysts as soon as it was formed. ► The process efficiency of the catalysis reaction was improved. Friedel–Crafts (FC) acylation is regarded as one of the key routes for graft substitution reaction. In this study, by-product HCl formed in the FC reaction has a major drawback inhibitory effect on the Lewis acid catalysts’ activity, and therefore reduces the FC reaction yield. With the need for more environmentally and economically benign processes, in situ inhibitor removal approach can be applied as a new strategy on one pot heterogeneous FC acylation. The inhibitor can be taken away from the vicinity of the catalysts as soon as it is formed. The chlorine weight percentage after FC acylation on polystyrene (PSt) microspheres under mild reaction conditions can be enhanced from 3.2% to 4.0% in acetone, from 2.9% to 3.6% in methanol, and from 4.4% to 5.3% in chloroform, respectively. It is important to note that the key feature of this reaction is operational simplicity and high yield. Keywords HCl Polystyrene microspheres Friedel–Crafts reaction In situ inhibitor removal 1 Introduction Aryl carbonyl compounds have garnered extensive attention as synthetic targets, most notably in the chemical production of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Common drugs such as naproxen, ibuprofen, fluribiprofen, and dichlofenac all contain this moiety [1,2]. Friedel–Crafts (FC) acylation reactions have served as one of the key premier routes to these products. In recent years, this methodology has become an emerging field and expanded to include esters, amides, and lactones as carbonyl coupling partners [3–8]. However, the catalytic activity of Lewis acid in FC process is easily inhibited by products as the reaction goes on, together with steric hindrance effect, which leads to the FC reaction yield and productivity economically infeasible. Consequently much attention has now been paid to eliminate the product inhibition on the Lewis acid catalysts in the liquid phase through the design of solid supported catalysts that can divide the catalysts and products in two different phases [1,3,6]. These solid–liquid biphase systems were carried out to prevent the products dissolved in the liquid phase from inhibiting the activity of solid supported Lewis acid catalysts. For example, solid zeolites, clay or resin-supported Lewis acids were found to be quite promising for FC acylation reactions of activated aromatic compounds [9–12]. Polystyrene (PSt) is a special type of important aromatic compound family, which are typically used in biomedical applications due to their ability to facilitate procedures such as cell sorting and immune precipitation [13–19]. However, it is essential to enable the matrix surface to be more hydrophilic in order to avoid irreversible interactions or protein denaturation. Thus, surface hydrophilization of the PSt beads should be performed by using hydrophilic polymer. The FC acylation or FC alkylation FC reaction is usually the first step for the functionalization of PSt microspheres, for example, bone graft substitution to the aromatic ring. However, since the conventional FC alkylation method uses highly carcinogenic chloromethyl ether as chloromethylation reagent, the development of PSt functional substitution through FC acylation reaction has gained much attention [17–24]. In normal practice, the catalyst in FC reaction was Lewis acid such as metal halides (AlCl3), with an acylation agent in a liquid solvent [4,5]. Actually, a stoichiometric excess of Lewis acid catalysts were used to provide favorable guarantee for the synthetic yield [6–8]. In FC acylation process of microspheres, the product acyl-PSt microspheres and the Lewis acid catalysts were in the solid and liquid phase, respectively, thus, it is regarded that the products have little effect on the catalytic activity. Previous uncharted, we find that by-product HCl formed in FC acylation process does not evaporate immediately, otherwise, is easily soluble in type of solvents used, which has a major drawback inhibitory effect on the synthetic efficiency according to some novel measurements such as laser scanning confocalmicroscope (LSCM). To the best of our knowledge, our work to this field is the study of inhibitor on heterogeneous FC acylation reaction catalyzed by Lewis acids, using in situ inhibitor removal strategy to enhance the catalysis process, which has virtually not been reported in the open literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Divinylbenzene (DVB, Dongda Chemical Engineering Group Co., China) was washed with 5wt% aqueous sodium hydroxide solution and deionized water, and dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate. Sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS, biochemical grade) was purchased from Merck. Sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), benzoyl peroxide (BPO, with 25wt% moisture content, reagent grade), heptane, tetrahydrofuran (THF), toluene, methanol, acetone, 1,2-dichloroethane, 4-methyl-2-pentanol, N,N-dimethylformamide, hydroquinone, chloroacetyl chloride, anhydrous aluminum chloride (AlCl3), anhydrous stannic chloride (SnCl4), anhydrous lithium chloride (LiCl) and other organic solvents were purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagents Company. Lauryl alcohol (LOH) was purchased from Tokyo Kasei Kogyo Co. Ltd. Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, degree of polymerization 1700, degree of hydrolysis 88.5%) was kindly provided by Kuraray (Japan). Polystyrene (PSt) was prepared by membrane emulsion polymerization. All the reagents were of analytic grade unless otherwise described. 2.2 Preparation of porous polystyrene microspheres The mixture of monomer and porogen dissolving BPO initiator and lauryl alcohol as interface stabilizer were used as dispersed phase. An aqueous solution of PVA (stabilizer), SDS (surfactant), Na2SO4 (electrolyte), and HQ (inhibitor) was used as continuous phase. The dispersed phase was pressed through the pores of the SPG (Shirasu Porous Glass) membrane into the aqueous phase continuously by applying nitrogen gas pressure. The membrane for emulsification was purchased from SPG Technology. 3.1, 5.2, 10.2-μm membranes were chosen in this study. The droplet size prepared was about four to six times as large as the pore size of the membrane. In this context, we noted a potential connection to our previous work demonstrating that the SPG membrane emulsification process provided emulsion products [13,14]. The obtained emulsion was transferred to a four-neck glass separator flask equipped with a semicircular anchor-type blade, a condenser, and a nitrogen inlet nozzle. The emulsion was bubbled with nitrogen gas for 1h. Then, the nozzle was lifted and the temperature was elevated to 80°C gradually. Then polymerization was carried out for 24h under nitrogen atmosphere. The prepared PSt microspheres were collected and washed with hot water and ethanol for four times, extracted in a Soxhlet apparatus with acetone, and then dried under vacuum. 2.3 Heterogeneous FC reaction Catalytic reactions were carried out in a four-neck glass flask fitted with a cooling condenser and in water bath. The batch experiments were equipped with mechanical stirring at 150rpm. An organic solvent was added into the pot to swell the PSt microspheres fully for 24h. The mass stoichiometric ratio (mL/g) between solvent and microsphere was 12.5:1. The mass stoichiometric ratio (mol/mol) of microsphere, Lewis acid catalyst (AlCl3, SnCl4, LiCl) and acylation agent was 1.0:1.1:1.2. 0.001–0.005vvm (air volume/culture volume/min) N2 was ventilated into the pot. The acylation formula was showed as below (Scheme 1 ). The benzene rings of microspheres undergo acylation predominantly at the para-position [4,15–17]. After the acylation reaction finished, the grafting PSt microspheres were collected and treated with cold hydrochloric acid (3%, w/v) to remove the catalyst. After filtering, the microspheres were washed with THF to remove residual solvent from the solid PSt, washed again with distilled water until free of chloride ions in the cleaning solution, and dried at 60°C under vacuum. In situ HCl removal process, solid sodium bicarbonate was used to capture the mineral acid (sodium bicarbonate/PSt=1:1mol/mol). 2.4 Preparation of HCl at different titers in solvent When H2SO4 in dropping funnel was dropped slowly into the solid NaCl in 200mL four-neck glass flask, HCl was produced and dissolved in the solvent. Different solvent systems dissolved HCl at saturated solubility at different temperature. The solvent dissolved HCl at saturation concentration was mixed with the same fresh solvent via stoichiometric ratio to prepare HCl at different concentration (Fig. 1 ). 2.5 HCl effect on catalytic reactions Aqueous organic solvents containing different concentrations of HCl were added individually to the catalytic reaction system. When the methanol was used as solvent, there were 100g methanol, 10.08g dried PSt microspheres, 25.2g SnCl4, 27.5g chloroacetyl chloride in the pot. When the acetone was used as solvent, there were 100g methanol, 10.25g dried PSt microspheres, 28.2g SnCl4, 30.7g chloroacetyl chloride in the pot. When the chloroform was used as solvent, there were 100g chloroform, 5.36g dried PSt microspheres, 13.4g SnCl4, 14.6g chloroacetyl chloride in the pot. The reaction time was controlled at 5h, and the temperature was chosen as 50°C. Chlorine weight percentage after FC acylation was measured to study the HCl inhibitory effect. 2.6 Characterization 2.6.1 Measurement of size distribution of microspheres The droplet diameters before and after polymerization were observed with an XSZ-H3 optical microscope (Coic, China). Diameters of about 400 droplets were counted to calculate the average diameter and the size distribution, which was expressed by a CV value. 2.6.2 Observation of surface feature of microspheres The morphology and porous features of microspheres were observed by JSM-6700F (JEOL, Japan) scanning electron microscopy (SEM). 2.6.3 Measurement of surface area and pore size of microspheres Specific surface area and pore size distribution of microspheres were characterized by BET nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements with a Quantasorb apparatus (Quantachrome Corp., USA) at 60°C. Samples were degassed under vacuum for 24h prior to data collection. 2.6.4 FT/IR spectra measurement of PSt and modified PSt The JASCO FT/IR 660 plus infrared spectrometer (JASCO, Japan) was used for Fourier transform infrared (FT/IR) analyses. 2.6.5 Zeta potentials and conductivity measurements Zeta potentials and conductivity of organic solvents and HCl-dissolved organic solvents were obtained in room temperature using Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern Instruments Ltd., UK) equipped with pH, conductivity probes. 2.6.6 Laser scanning confocalmicroscope (LSCM) measurement Fluorescein isothiocyanate isomer I (FITC)-labeling acylated PSt microspheres adsorption experiments were conducted in a 4°C incubator, 200rpm. After 24h adsorption, the microspheres were separated from the FITC solution by centrifugation and washed with pH 8.0, 0.05M PBS buffer five times to remove residual FITC molecules completely. After being placed on a slide glass and being covered with cover glass, the microspheres were observed with a TCS SP2 laser scanning confocalmicroscope (LSCM) (Leica, Germany) to visualize the FC acylation efficiency of FITC-labeling chloroacetyl chloride onto PSt microspheres. Chloroacetyl PSt microspheres can be marked by FITC, while unmodified PSt microspheres cannot. The samples were detected at 488nm of excitation wavelengths, and the fluorescent images at 520–550nm wavelengths were then taken. 2.6.7 Measurement of acylation yield The microspheres were firstly dried at 105°C for 2h. 0.1g dried microspheres, 1.5g potassium nitrate 2g sodium hydroxide were measured and put into a Ni-pot. The mixture was burned out. The chlorine element contained in the sample was washed fully and transformed into chloride ions with deionized water. Subsequently, the traditional Volhard method was adopted to analyze the chlorine content (wt%). The chlorine weight percentage measured was used to show the FC acylation yield. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of PSt microspheres Uniformly sized crosslinked PSt microspheres with high specific surface areas and narrow size distribution were synthesized by membrane emulsification technique as starting materials for acylation. The span value of PSt microspheres was 0.688 with a crosslinking degree of 20%. The average diameter, pore size and specific surface area were 29.2μm, 14.3nm and 502m2/g. Meanwhile, FC catalysts, liquid acylation agents and inorganic salts can easily accumulate on the surface of PSt microspheres (Fig. 2a). Thus, a strict washing step was needed for the further modification or synthesis processes (Fig. 2b). FT/IR analysis showed a band at 670cm−1 ascribed to the stretching vibration absorption of –CCl bond in chloroacyl group, which confirmed that solid-phase acylation on PSt microspheres actually occurred (Fig. 3 ). 3.2 Inhibitor of the PSt FC acylation processes HCl was a conventional mineral acid by-product of the FC acylation processes catalyzed by many metal halides Lewis acids. According to measurement, we found HCl was quite soluble in many aspects of common acylation solvents used in reaction system. Table 1 showed the solubility of HCl was substantially different in different solvents at different temperatures under normal pressure. When methanol was used as the acylation solvent, the saturated HCl can reach nearly 100.2g/100.0g methanol. The solubility of HCl in solvent followed the order as methanol>ethanol>acetone> n-butanol>glycerol> n-hexane>chloroform. Several polar solvents resulted in high HCl solubility. Thus, the polarity of solvent was one of key factors affecting the inhibitor concentration. The chlorine weight percentage after FC acylation on PSt microspheres varied dramatically at different initial inhibitory concentrations of HCl. Varied organic solvents were used as the swelling and mixing reagents. Fig. 6a showed the inhibitory effect on the chlorine weight percentage when the titers of HCl were less than 5g/100g methanol, 5g/100g acetone and 5g/1000g chloroform, respectively. As the increase of HCl concentrations, the chlorine weight percentage decreased and finally maintained at a certain degree. The reason of low FC reaction yield was still under worldwide research. A function of Lewis acid catalysts was to stabilize the transient carbocations and maintain a proper chiral form for reaction. Mineral acids can challenge with Lewis acids to interrupt the enantioselective reactions, which decreased the activity of Lewis acid catalyst. Especially, when acetone was used as the solvent, the colorless acetone turned extremely red after dissolved multivalent metal cations from Lewis acids catalysts. The possible reason was that the Al3+/Sn4+/Li+–acetone complexes possessed a significantly large red shift [26,27]. Zeta (ζ) potential is a measure of the electrical potential that causes interparticle repulsion. The ζ potential is correlated with the rheological properties of dispersions [28], and this correlation can be used in the formulation of modified microspheres. Fig. 4 shows ζ potential changed dramatically when HCl dissolved in the different solvents. In detail, the pure solvents acetone, methanol and chloroform had a ζ potential of −14.2mV, +4.96mV and +2.12mV, respectively. However, HCl-saturated acetone, methanol and chloroform had a ζ potential of +0.13mV, −3.56mV and +3.02mV, respectively. These values were not surprising, considering that the mineral acid (HCl) had a disturbance on the solution environment and therefore reduced the FC catalysis efficiency. Moreover, HCl had the different effect on the acylation solvents, for example, the ζ potential of chloroform was less affected than the other solvents. For the enhancement of heterogeneous FC reaction with Lewis acids catalysts, the conductivity should stay approximately constant. However, HCl had an important effect on the conductivity of acylation solvents. Fig. 5 shows conductivity changed dramatically when HCl dissolved in the different solvents. The pure solvents acetone, methanol and chloroform had a conductivity of 6.95×10−4 mS/cm, 0.0612mS/cm and 2.04×10−4 mS/cm, respectively. However, HCl-saturated acetone, methanol and chloroform had a conductivity of 3.01×10−4 mS/cm, 14.0mS/cm and 3.77×10−4 mS/cm, respectively. Moreover, HCl had a huge effect on the conductivity of methanol, which resulted in a 228-fold increase of conductivity. The soluble H+ can be adsorbed to the intermediate of the FC acylation process (Scheme 1), thus, affect the FC catalysis efficiency and finally reduced the catalysis yield. 3.3 In situ inhibitor removal enhanced PSt FC acylation Present industrial practice requires a stoichiometric amount of soluble Lewis acids (e.g., AlCl3) or strong mineral acids (e.g., HF) as catalysts [3–5]. Although a number of economically infeasible and green Lewis acid catalysts had been found to facilitate FC acylation, by-product mineral acids dissolved in solvent inhibited acylation after accumulation to a certain concentrations. In this study, solid neutralization agent sodium bicarbonate was chose for in situ mineral acid removal, which was an efficient approach to remove the inhibitory by-product from the vicinity of the catalysts as soon as it is formed. As shown in Fig. 6b, the chlorine weight percentage was improved from 3.2% to 4.0% in acetone, from 2.9% to 3.6% in methanol, and from 4.4% to 5.3% in chloroform, respectively. In situ mineral acid removal can avoid direct contact between by-product and Lewis acids in liquid environment, and increase the yield by overcoming the inhibitory or toxic effects of by-product. Mineral acid can be neutralized by sodium bicarbonate, and conversed to carbon dioxide gas and solid sodium chloride. Sodium chloride was insoluble in organic solvents used. For example, the solubility of sodium chloride at normal temperature was 0.05g/g ethanol. The major roles of acylation solvents were PSt microspheres swelling, Lewis acids dissolving and reagents mixing [15,17,19]. As HCl had a relatively low solubility in chloroform, HCl showed little effect on the ζ potential and conductivity of in chloroform system, and the 4.4% chlorine content in chloroform system was obtained without in situ HCl removal (Fig. 6b). Laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM) was used to study the HCl inhibition effect for the first time. As shown in figure below, much less fluorescence was detected from the surface of acylated PSt micropsheres under HCl inhibition (Fig. 7a), while great fluorescent acylated PSt micropsheres were observed with a high chlorine weight percentage after FC acylation with in situ HCl removal treatment (Fig. 7b). This comparative study provided a straight insight on the HCl inhibition effect on FC acylation on PSt microspheres. 3.4 Factors affected PSt FC acylation processes After initial optimization, we investigated other factors that affected PSt FC acylation processes. As the acylation reaction can easily occurred on the swelling PSt microspheres, smaller microsphere diameters contributed to relatively higher specific surface area and inner critical pathway, which improved the acylation yield (Fig. 8a). Insufficient solvent (15mL) cannot swell PSt microspheres sufficiently. But the additional crosslinking reaction easily occurred in less solvent volume [17]. If the volume of the solvent continuously increased, the concentrations of the chloroacylation reagent became lower, resulting in a declining of the chlorine content (Fig. 8b). Although the acidity of the three Lewis acid catalysts follows the order: AlCl3 >SnCl4 >LiCl, under the same reaction conditions SnCl4 enabled the highest yield reaction. These Lewis acids can dissolve in many organic solvents totally. AlCl3 had strong ability to accept electron from the benzene ring of PSt microspheres, which caused fragmentation of the microspheres and affected the modification processes [17–20]. SnCl4 was a suitable Lewis acid catalyst for the FC acylation of PSt microspheres (Fig. 8c). Initially, as a plenty of hydrogen atoms in benzene ring of microspheres was available for substitution reaction, the yield increased. As time went by, the content of the chloroacyl group on PSt microspheres may decrease, since some additional crosslinking occurred [4,17]. Amount of catalyst was one of key factors affecting the acylation processes [21]. As the increase of catalyst amounts, the chlorine weight percentage increased. When the stoichiometric ratio (mol/mol) between SnCl4 and PSt was more than 1.1, the chlorine weight percentage did not changed (Fig. 8d). Fig. 8e showed when the ratio of acylation reagent/PSt (mol/mol) was less than 1.2:1, the chlorine weight percentage increased together with increase of acylation reagent. If the stoichiometric ratio was more than 1.2:1, the chlorine weight percentage did not increase. As the acylation reaction occurred, steric hindrance of the PSt linkage network affected the molecular interaction which resulted the maximum reaction yield. Fig. 8f showed the effect of temperature on the yield. Chiral, functional Lewis-acid catalysts stabilized the transient carbocations and were able to mediate enantioselective reactions under the proper temperature [10–12]. High temperature can accelerate the formation of carbocations so as to improve the FC reaction [9]. After one batch reaction, the acyl-PSt microspheres were cleaned and dried. We hoped to increase the chlorine weight percentage. Thus, the acyl-PSt microspheres were put into the reaction pot again under the same acylation condition. The fed-batch strategy was typically used in catalyst-industrial processes to overcome product/by-product inhibition with a high yield or productivity in the reactor. However, the fed-batch strategy cannot improve chlorine weight percentage in this study. One batch reaction was enough for the FC acylation (Fig. 8g). 4 Conclusions In summary, mineral acid can inhibit Lewis acids catalysts in heterogeneous FC reaction system. In situ inhibitor removal is a successful strategy to improve the heterogeneous acylation efficiency under mild reaction conditions, which render the process economically attractive. Short reaction times, easy work-up, high yields, and easy performing of the process are other obvious advantages of the present method. Acknowledgments Financial support by the National Science Foundation of China (No. 21206175, 20820102036 and No. 51103158) and by the Beijing Natural Science Foundation (Preparation of polystyrene particles with diverse physical properties and evaluation of the effect on cellular response) were gratefully acknowledged. coredata.dc:description: Friedel–Crafts (FC) acylation is regarded as one of the key routes for graft substitution reaction. In this study, by-product HCl formed in the FC reaction has a major drawback inhibitory effect on the Lewis acid catalysts’ activity, and therefore reduces the FC reaction yield. With the need for more environmentally and economically benign processes, in situ inhibitor removal approach can be applied as a new strategy on one pot heterogeneous FC acylation. The inhibitor can be taken away from the vicinity of the catalysts as soon as it is formed. The chlorine weight percentage after FC acylation on polystyrene (PSt) microspheres under mild reaction conditions can be enhanced from 3.2% to 4.0% in acetone, from 2.9% to 3.6% in methanol, and from 4.4% to 5.3% in chloroform, respectively. It is important to note that the key feature of this reaction is operational simplicity and high yield.
coredata.dc:title: In situ inhibitor (HCl) removal promoted heterogeneous Friedel–Crafts reaction of polystyrene microsphere with Lewis acids catalysts
